questions.text: FEV1 / FVC is reduced in all of the following conditions EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

FEV1/FVC also called as the Tiffaneau’s Index is the most accurate parameter of the Spirometry. The index is reduced in Obstructive lung disease which includes Asthma, Chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
In Restrictive lung diseases, it is normal or high.

questions.text: All of the following are expected Spirometry changes in Kyphoscoliosis except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Kyphoscoliosis is a restrictive disease showing increased  or normal FEV1/FVC ratio.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with fatigue and exercise intolerance since 4 months, her FVC is 90%, FEV1/FVC IS 86%, SpO2 after 6-minute walk test was observed to drop from 90 to 86%. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
6-minute walk test showing more than 3% reduction SpO2 is considered as a marker of hypoxemia. The FVC is normal with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio excluding both obstructive and restrictive lung disease. The third mechanism for hypoxemia is an isolated defect of diffusion as seen in Pulmonary hypertension.
Pulmonary hypertension is most common among young females and in early stages comes with vague symptoms as fatigue and poor effort tolerance.

questions.text: DLCO is decreased in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

DLCO: (Diffusion capacity of Lung to Carbon mono-oxide)
DECREASED DLCO    INCREASED DLCO
Emphysema    Acute Asthma
Interstitial Lung diseases (ILD)    Alveolar Hemorrhage e.g. Good Pastures syndrome, Wegener’s granulomatosis
Pulmonary Hypertension    Chronic, congestive heart failure
Acute LVF / Shock    Polycythemia
Anemia

questions.text: Most common mechanism in Hypoxemia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ventilation perfusion mismatch is most common

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of definition of ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ARDS is the most severe form of lung injury presenting as Type 1 Respiratory failure due to alveolar atelectasis presenting as bilateral, perihilar pulmonary infiltrates on Radiology.
Type 1 RF has hypoxemia leading to compensatory hyperventilation (Hypocapnea).

choices.text: Ventilation at tidal volumes of 6ml per kg

questions.text: The following have been shown to avoid ventilator associated lung injury  in ARDS:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Low TV ventilation (6ml/kg) is the main recommendation for mechanical ventilation in ARDS. Since >70% of alveoli are collapsed, giving full TV will lead to overdistension and rupture of the normal remaining alveoli.

choices.text: The timing of ARDS must occur 1 week of a known clinical insult and new or worsening respiratory symptoms.
Bilateral opacities are evident on chest imaging, which are not attributable to effusions, lobar collapse or pulmonary nodules.
The respiratory failure seen cannot be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. .
Severe ARDS is defined by a Pa02/Fi02 ratio of > 300 with a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) >5cmH2O.

questions.text: Regarding the Berlin definition for ARDS, all statements are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 (PaO2/FiO2) <300 when patient is on mechanical ventilator with a PEEP>5cm H2O is diagnostic of ARDS

questions.text: In acute Pulmonary embolism most common ECG finding
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

S1Q3T3 pattern is most specific but rarely found on the ECG.
Sinus tachycardia is most common but nonspecific. Hence, ECG is no longer needed to diagnose PTE.

questions.text: The principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MDCT-PA (Multi-detector CT Pulmonary Angiography) is the principal imaging test for diagnosis of PTE. Only if it is contraindicated (e.g. Pregnancy) – VQ scan can be done instead.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is known to decrease mortality in critically ill COVID pt ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The RECOVERY trial provides evidence that treatment with dexamethasone at a dose of 6 mg once daily for up to 10 days reduces 28-day mortality in patients with Covid-19 who are receiving respiratory support.

questions.text: In patients with severe structural lung disease, such as bronchiectasis, the infective agent most likely to cause pneumonia is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa followed by Staph.

questions.text: Atypical pneumonia can be caused by all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, Staph and Streptococci are included under organisms causing classical pneumonia.

choices.text: Most patients have CD4 counts <200 at the time of diagnosis of their first episode PCP
Most patients with PCP will have an elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase level.
ABG can reveal PaO2 < 60mm of hg and a widened alveolo-arterial gradient
A normal chest radiograph rules out the diagnosis

questions.text: Regarding Pneumocystis pneumonia in HIV-infected patients all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

PCP can cause disease only in immune-compromised patient. It can cause hypoxemia with elevated A-a gradient (pulmonary cause) and elevated LDH. Chest-ray maybe normal in early stages. BAL can confirm disease by demonstrating pneumocystis

choices.text: OP treatment with Clarithromycin 500mg BID for one week
Admit in ward and give Levofloxacin orally 750mg OD + Inj. Ceftriaxone 1G IV BID
Admit in ICCU and give Inj. Ceftriaxone 2G IV OD + IV levofloxacin 750mg OD
Admit in wards and give Piperacillin + tazobactam 4.5 G qid

questions.text: A 30 year previously healthy male came with 2 days fever and cough with purulent sputum. Examination reveals an impaired note with bronchial breathing and crackles and increased vocal resonance. He is alert. Pulse-106/min, BP=100/70. Respiratory rate =24/min. Blood urea=6 mmol/L. Which of the following is the best treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Using CURB65 score to grade the severity of Pneumonia, the above patient can be classified as Mild pneumonia which can be treated on OPD basis with monotherapy using Azithro/Clarithromycin.

questions.text: A 56 year old lady is admitted with a history of sudden onset of right sided pleuritic chest pain and breathlessness. Oxygen saturations are 94% on air, respiratory rate 22/minute, pulse rate 110/minute, BP 85/60. CXR is normal. D-Dimer positive. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. CT-PA confirms bilateral pulmonary embolus. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thrombolysis

The clinical severity of PE is variable, ranging from asymptomatic through to respiratory failure, circulatory collapse and death. Treatment is dependent on the clinical severity of the patient. The majority of patients are treated with anticoagulation, initially LMWH followed by warfarin. In patients with high risk PE, with shock or persistent hypotension, the risk of haemorrhage from thombolysis is outweighed by the benefits of thrombolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of polysomnography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intra arterial oxygen monitoring

Components of polysomnography : 
EEG- Electro encephalography , EOG - Electro oculography, ECG- Electro cardiography, EMG Electro myo graphy , Spo2 , Snoring MIC , Nasal/Oral Airflow , Thoracic Effort & Abdominal Effort and  Body Position. Intra arterial oxygen monitoring is not part of polysomnography.

questions.text: CURB 65 includes all except     ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

BP<90/60mm is a criterion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female comes with acute SOB, neck vein distention, absent breath sounds and mediastinal shift. Which one of the following to be done immediately?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acute breathlessness with absent breath sounds suggests pneumothorax. Immediate treatment is to insert large bore needle followed by Intercostal drainage tube.

choices.text: Positive Gram stain or culture of pleural fluid

questions.text: Factors indicating the likely need for a procedure more invasive than a thoracentesis are all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
ICD tube placement is needed only if the Pleural effusion is loculated/hemorrhagic/empyema.
Empyema can be suspected by: 
1. Gross pus on physical appearance
2. Pleural fluid pH<7.20
3. Pleural fluid Glucose <60
4. Loculated pleural effusion
5. Gram stain or culture positive.

choices.text: Skin test negative for common inhalant allergens

questions.text: Following statements about non atopic asthma is false
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Non-atopic is another name for Idiosyncratic/Intrinsic asthma.

choices.text: > 200 ml increase in FeV1 after bronchodilator

questions.text: In a patient with clinical signs of asthma which of the following tests will suggest diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asthma is characterized by obstructive pattern with excellent Broncho-reversibility (increase in FEV1 > 12% or > 200ml) after bronchodilator.

choices.text: Have the patient demonstrate his inhaler technique

questions.text: A 37/M with asthma is evaluated for frequent episodes of wheezing and dyspnea unrelieved by short-acting β-agonist therapy. He uses his controller medications regularly, including an inhaled long-acting β-agonist and inhaled high-dose corticosteroids. Spirometry shows an FEV1 of 65% of predicted. After the supervised use of a bronchodilator in the office, there was some relief of symptoms, and repeat spirometry 10 minutes after the administration of SABA showed that the FEV1 increased to 85% of predicted. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in this patient’s management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)	

Since the response is better under supervision at office, it is likely that the problem is incorrect technique of inhalation.

questions.text: Bronchial thermoplasty is approved in treatment of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: You are asked to see a 26 year old lady in the  emergency department who has been brought in complaining of dyspnoea and chest tightness. On examination pulse rate is 130/minute, respiratory rate 32/minute and there is a widespread expiratory wheeze on auscultation. Oxygen saturations are 96% on 5L Oxygen . She has been given hydrocortisone injection , back to back nebulised bronchodilators and still widespread wheeze heard.  What treatment would you instigate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: All are true Rheumatoid arthritis associated Plef except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: In COPD management most important intervention is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Smoking is the most important risk factor. Even before prophylaxis, cessation of smoking is essential.

choices.text: Intradermal testing using Aspergillus fumigatus antigen is positive
Sputum culture positive for Aspergillus fumigatus.

questions.text: Major Diagnostic features of allergic broncho-pulmonary aspergillosis [ABPA] include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ABPA is a hypersentivity reaction and not infection. Hence, sputum culture is not major diagnostic feature

questions.text: Farmer’s Lung is caused due to exposure to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 40 year old miner, presents to his primary care physician complaining of dyspnea and chronic dry cough. Pathological findings include lower lobe interstitial fibrosis. Frontal CXR SHOWS egg shell calcification of hilar lymph nodes and reticular abnormalities with apical fibrosis, the most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A Female presents with history of progressive breathlessness. Histology shows heterogenous patchy fibrosis with several fibroblastic foci. The most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Biopsy is conclusive.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for interstitial disease is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)	

HRCT showing Ground glass opacities with mosaic pattern is confirmatory.

choices.text: Condition is seen most commonly in those younger than 30 years
It presents as a clinical syndrome of idiopathic ARDS
It is associated with low mortality
Lung biopsy is not required for confirming the diagnosis

questions.text: What is false about acute interstitial pneumonitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

AIP (Hamman Rich syndrome) mimics ARDS and has >70%mortality with poor response to steroids.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding non specific interstitial pneumonia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 20 years old women presents with a dry cough and dyspnoea. A Chest X-ray has been performed and demonstrates bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with bilateral well defined 3mm parenchymal nodules. The diagnosis is most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sarcoidosis affects the lungs in 4 stages.
Stage 1: Only Hilar adenopathy
Stage 2: Hilar LN plus pulmonary infiltrates
Stage 3: Only pulmonary infiltrates
Stage 4: Interstitial fibrosis

questions.text: A woman admitted with C/O low grade fever 6 weeks duration and CXR shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. All of the following investigations are used except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CD4:CD8 ratio in BAL (Not blood) >3.5 is specific for Sarcoidosis.

questions.text:
Consider the following criteria: 
1. Pleural fluid protein: Serum protein ratio> 0.5 
2. Pleural fluid LDH: Serum LDH ratio > 0-6 
3. Pleural fluid LDH > Two-thirds of the upper limit of normal serum LDH 
Which of the above criteria, if present in pleural fluid, will indicate an exudate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

choices.text: World wide squamous cell variant accounts for 70% of all lung cancers
Small  cell variant typically presents with cavitation
Small cell variant is typically associated with smoking
Adenocarcinoma variant is typically central in location

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lung carcinoma is true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Small cell variant is typically associated with smoking

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with features of fever and productive cough with postural increase. He has a history of binge drinking. X-ray of the patient shown below: What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lung abscess due to aspiration is caused by oral anaerobes & best treated with IV Clindamycin.

questions.text: A 60 y M presenting with polyuria, pain abdomen, nausea, vomiting, altered sensorium was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma and hypercalcemia. The histological variant can be mostly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Squamous
Squamous cell carcinoma can cause life threatening hypercalcemia

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct with regard to clubbing? 

1. It usually affects the fingers symmetrically. 

2. It does not involve the toes. 

3. It may be associated with malignant lung conditions. 

4. It may recede following the lung transplantation in cystic fibrosis. 

Select the answer using the code given below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Exact mechanism unknown. Recent theory : deposition of growth factors at tip of fingers & toes as part of few systemic disorders that results in proliferation of tissue & bulbous enlargement of finger & toes. Seen respiratory diseases like ILD, Bronchiectasis , Lung abscess, malignancy .

questions.text: The distance walked in 6 minutes is an indirect measure of which of the following variables of the 'BODE Index' which is used to assess the prognosis in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): 
1.  Exudative phase lasts from day 7 to day 21 after exposure to a precipitating risk factor.
2.  Proliferative phase is characterised by proliferation of type II pneumocytes. 
3. Low tidal volume ventilation (6 ml/kg body weight) has significantly lower mortality in management as compared to high tidal volume ventilation (12) mL/kg body weight). 
4. PaO/FiO2  < 100 mm Hg is classified as severe ARDS. 
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


•    Damage to capillary endothelium & alveolar epithelium at multiple sites in both lungs                                                                                 leading to increased accumulation of neutrophis & alvelor damage Exudative phase (0 – 7days)
•    Proliferative phase  ( 7-21 days) : Recovery alveolar epithelial proliferation
•    Fibrotic phase  (> 21 days )  : Fibrosis & mortality
•    PaO2 / FiO2 ratio < 100 mmHg is Severe ARDS

questions.text:
Consider the following statements with regard to pulmonary embolism: 
1. Unexplained breathlessness is the most common symptom. 
2. When congestive heart failure or pneumonia fail to improve despite standard medical treatment, occult pulmonary embolism should be considered. 
3. Patients with high clinical likelihood of venous thromboembolism should first undergo D-dimer testing alone without obligatory imaging tests. 
Which of the statements given above are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Unexplained breathlessness can be  most common symptom in PE. When congestive heart failure or pneumonia fail to improve despite standard medical treatment, occult pulmonary embolism should be considered.  Patients with high clinical likelihood of venous thromboembolism should first undergo CTPA

choices.text: Most common site of collection is Radial artery
0.1ml of heparin is taken prior to take blood sample
If modified Allen's test is positive; opposite hand is used
Even though PH and PaCO2 are normal, ABB defect maybe present.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong related to ABG analysis.?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Modified Allen’s test positive indicates competence of ulnar artery to supply the palmar arch alone. Hence, you can proceed with sample collection with the hand.

choices.text: Normal–anion-gap metabolic acidosis and compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.text: An 84-year-old female was found to have a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg, heart rate 101beats/min, temperature 37.8°C. Laboratory data are obtained: sodium 137 meq/L, potassium 2.8meq/L, HCO3 10 meq/L, chloride 117 meq/L, BUN 17 mg/dL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL. An arterial blood gas shows PaO2 80 mmHg, PCO2 24 mmHg, pH 7.29. Her urine analysis is clear and has a Ph of 4.5. What is the acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Steps in ABG
1. See the PH : Acidosis or Alkalosis
2. Check for primary disorder : Respiratory or metabolic
3. See for compensation.
a.IF primary was respiratory process , calculate metabolic compensation. If primary was metabolic calculate respiratory compensation
b. If given value is with in the expected value then it is a simple acid base disorder
c. If given value is not correlating with expected value then it will be a inappropriate compensation / mixed disorder.
4. Calculate Anion gap
Acidosis is correlating more to fall in HCO3 so its metabolic acidosis.
Expected PaCO2 = [1.5 × HCO3] +8 +-2 that give the value of 21 to 25mmhg. Here the given PaCO2 is correlating with expected value which will suggest metabolic acidosis and compensatory alkalosis. Anion gap is also with in normal range

choices.text: Non anion gap Metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A diabetic patient with following parameters : Na+, 140; K+, 4.0; Cl-, 106; pH, 7.31 Paco2 : 30 HCO3-, 14
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: ABG PH 7.2, PaCO2 60 mmhg, hco3 19 meq/l, diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In simple acid base disorder always primary change and compensation move together. When CO2 and HCO3 move in opposite direction, it is mixed. 
HCO3  is going down so metabolic acidosis and CO2 high, so respiratory acidosis also ie 
Respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis. Without clinical H/o difficult to comment regarding the initiating process

questions.text: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Diarrhea, Pancreatic fistula and Renal tubular acidosis are causes of Normal Anion gap acidosis.

choices.text: Can be caused by Liddle’s syndrome
Can be caused due to Primary hyperaldosteronism
Can be caused due to Renin secreting tumor

questions.text: All are true about metabolic alkalosis except one
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)
